conversation.content: [defensively] My mom and stepdad aren't home right now, but they said someone would be coming by for the annual inspection, so I guess you can come in.
[professionally] I appreciate that, and I'll need to check all the units throughout the house, including bedrooms and the basement if you have one. Should take about forty-five minutes.
The basement's locked actually, and Mark doesn't like anyone going down there without him being present, so maybe you could skip that part today?
[firmly] I'm afraid that's not how this works—state fire code requires inspection of all areas, especially basements where electrical panels and heating systems are typically located.
[nervously] Look, I'm seventeen, I don't have the key, and Mark will literally lose his mind if I let someone down there while he's gone.
You mentioned Mark, that's your stepfather? [pauses] I'm noticing some unusual burn patterns on this hallway ceiling that weren't in last year's report.
[quickly] Those are from a candle accident a few months ago, my mom already filed the insurance claim and everything, totally documented and legitimate.
Candle accidents don't typically create pour patterns like these—see how the damage radiates outward in multiple directions? That suggests an accelerant was used.
[voice dropping] You don't understand what you're getting into here, and I really think you should just mark everything as passing and leave before they get back.
[concerned] Son, I've been doing this for twenty years, and what I'm seeing here, combined with your reaction, tells me something serious happened in this house. Are you safe here?
[barely audible] Please just go.

I can't leave without completing the inspection, but more importantly, these burn patterns, the way you're protecting that basement, [exhales], I'm legally required to report suspected arson to the fire marshal.
[desperately] It wasn't arson, it was self-defense, okay? Mark had Mom cornered in the kitchen and I grabbed the lighter fluid from the grill and just, I wanted to scare him.
You're telling me you used lighter fluid to protect your mother from your stepfather, and now you're alone in this house waiting for them to return?
[trembling] They made me promise never to tell anyone, said foster care would be worse, that we're a family and families handle things internally no matter what happens.
Listen to me very carefully—what you're describing is not normal family behavior, it's abuse, and you defending your mother doesn't make you the problem here.
You think I don't know that? But she chose him over getting us out, and now I'm stuck playing this game where we all pretend everything's fine. [bitter laugh]
[gently] I'm going to call this in, but not as arson—as a welfare check requiring immediate response, which means police and social services will be here within the hour.
[resigned] Mark keeps a gun in that basement he's not supposed to have because of his record, so maybe mention that when you call it in.
[pulling out phone] I'm staying right here with you until help arrives, and we're going to wait outside by my truck where it's visible and safe, okay?
